seg.seg: ... He does bad deed[s]. He trades the price of the Saṃgha. ...
... Avoid [pl.] all [idle or evil] talks! Like the horrible, sharp-xy (weapons? army?) of the enemy ...
... to the hells beginning with the Avīci [hell]. Because of bad friends these ones ... innumerable ...
... in the retinues of the good ones. The snakes/insects (?) frighten (because of) aversion ...
... Avoid [pl.] the possessions! Because of the excellent garment of good conduct one renounces ...
... they spread ... . 28. One should lie [and] sit on the grass, one should eat alms ...
... in order to observe the good conduct. By whom the noble good conduct [has to be] taken as concern, he should avoid the four things [= errors].
If you do not tell the truth before, afterwards you will suffer in the truth.
If you [pl.] say the untrue before, you stay in truth afterwards. (Georges-Jean Pinault, p.c.)
There was a rich householder; he was the brother of Narahānt. This one (did something) to that one ...
... pretexts. He kept telling this sort of words. 30. “For me [there is] no opportunity ...”
This miserable has been reborn among oxen. This monk saw him ...
... you (sg.) ... in the truth ... you (sg.) kept saying (that) while remaining in the house ...

p.note: There are several forms with o-mobile immediately in front of a colon/pāda end, i.e., in the normal position in verse.

The meter seems to be 4 x 14 (7/7), but in a5 we have an eight-syllable colon. In a2 and a4 two cross signs slightly above the line can be seen; usually, this sign marks a correction, but here nothing was added or deleted. The crosses may, however, signal the omission of a whole pāda or stanza, since the written stanza numbers are difficult to reconcile with the lacunas, i.e. it seems that text is indeed missing.

The actual piece consists of two joint fragments, only the left part of which has been edited by Lévi and commented upon by Sieg. Only due to this joint giving clear stanza numbers it has been possible to distinguish between recto and verso side. Hence, the actual sides are in the reverse order in contrast to the first edition.

The text contains the otherwise unknown ṣlātäṃ, but since there is a corrections cross after this form (though without visible correction), it is quite reasonable to assume a correction to plātäṃ ‘talks, speeches’. The form matre must be the first member of a compound, as in matre-wse ‘having a sharp poison’.
There are two variants of the 2.pl. active transitive Imperative of wik(ā)-, pwikso (a2) and pwīkaso (a5), no doubt due to metrical requirements.

The reading °īyaṃne by Lévi is certain; hence the assumption by 4 to read °īyeṃne and to simply restore (kerc)īyeṃne is wrong. Actually, the restoration (w)[er](ts)īyaṃne makes much more sense with respect to the context. The segmentation of the akṣarsas before the verb parskäskeṃ is uncertain. We may deal with the adverb yaka; lokek could in theory be a form of lauke plus emphatic -k. However, the connection of these two adverbs with ‘frighten’ is not clear semantically. Therefore, one may venture the guess that lokekyaka is based on an incorrect sanskritization of a Middle Indic form of Sanskrit lohitaka- ‘some sort of insect’ (465b) or of Skt. lohitākṣa- ‘with red eyes’ (the name of a snake) (M-W, 909b). Accordingly, lokekyaka would be the plural of a noun lokekyak*. As for ykeṃ, the only sensible interpretation is to regard it as a form of an adverb yṅkeṃ ‘on the earth’ comparable to iṅkauṃ ‘by day’; note that the nasal in these formations may be missing (cf. yñakteṃ, yśāmna). It is unclear what the cross means, since there is no written correction.

If -sa is the perlative affix (which is the only sensible semantic solution), it is wrongly placed after the adjective (instead of the substantive wassi). In addition, this clause has one syllable to many. One may surmise that the original, metrically correct text had the verse form śilṣesa. The copyist transposed it into the usual prose form.

The reading of the number 28 as per Lévi is certain (pace 4). One has to admit, however, that the restitution of the meter from the number of syllables (taking the pāda digits for granted) is difficult.
The 2. plural middle kalträ is the first attestation of the expected zero-grade stem of the Sub I stem of käl- ‘to suffer, endure’ (1.sg. kelu).
Due to context narahānte is a genitive singular of a proper name Narahānt, which is obviously borrowed from Sanskrit, possibly a false rendering of narānta-.
